answer_html: Notice that the left hand limit is also positive infinity since the second term can be written as \(\displaystyle 3x^{-2/5} = \frac{3}{\sqrt[5]{x^2}}\) which is always positive.
answer_latex:
Notice that the left hand limit is also positive infinity since the
second term can be written as
$\displaystyle 3x^{-2/5} = \frac{3}{\sqrt[5]{x^2}}$ which is always
positive.
hints_html: Check points of the function where it is not continuous and verify that one of the left or right hand limits are positive or negative infinity.
hints_latex:
Check points of the function where it is not continuous and verify that
one of the left or right hand limits are positive or negative infinity.
hints_raw: Check points of the function where it is not continuous and verify that one of the left or right hand limits are positive or negative infinity.
question: 6 (e)
sols_html:
As given in the original statement, the function has domain of all nonzero reals. The function itself is only not continuous at 0 so we check there for an asymptote.

The value

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to 0^{+}}(2x^{3/5} + 3x^{-2/5}) = \infty\end{aligned}\]

since this function when we plug in values of x slightly bigger than 0, the first term tends to 0 and the second term tends to positive infinity.

Notice that the left hand limit is also positive infinity since the second term can be written as \(\displaystyle 3x^{-2/5} = \frac{3}{\sqrt[5]{x^2}}\) which is always positive.
sols_latex:
As given in the original statement, the function has domain of all
nonzero reals. The function itself is only not continuous at 0 so we
check there for an asymptote.

The value

\begin{align*}
\lim_{x \to 0^{+}}(2x^{3/5} + 3x^{-2/5}) = \infty
\end{align*} since this function when we plug in values of \emph{x}
slightly bigger than 0, the first term tends to 0 and the second term
tends to positive infinity.

Notice that the left hand limit is also positive infinity since the
second term can be written as
$\displaystyle 3x^{-2/5} = \frac{3}{\sqrt[5]{x^2}}$ which is always
positive.
sols_raw:
As given in the original statement, the function has domain of all nonzero reals. The function itself is only not continuous at 0 so we check there for an asymptote.

The value

<math>
\begin{align}
\lim_{x \to 0^{+}}(2x^{3/5} + 3x^{-2/5}) = \infty
\end{align}
</math>
since this function when we plug in values of ''x'' slightly bigger than 0, the first term tends to 0 and the second term tends to positive infinity.

Notice that the left hand limit is also positive infinity since the second term can be written as <math> \displaystyle 3x^{-2/5} = \frac{3}{\sqrt[5]{x^2}} </math> which is always positive.
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 5-11, justify your answers and show all your work. If a box is provided, write your final answer there. Unless otherwise indicated, simplification of numerical answers is required in these questions.

6. Let \(f(x) = 2x^{3/5} + 3x^{-2/5}\). Note that the domain of \(f\) is the set of all nonzero real numbers; for example, \(f(-1) = -2 + 3 = 1\).

(e) Find all vertical asymptotes of the graph \(y = f(x)\).

\textbf{Full-Solution Problems}. In questions 5-11, justify your answers
and \textbf{show all your work}. If a box is provided, write your final
answer there. \textbf{Unless otherwise indicated, simplification of
numerical answers is required in these questions.}

6. Let $f(x) = 2x^{3/5} + 3x^{-2/5}$. Note that the domain of $f$ is the
set of all nonzero real numbers; for example, $f(-1) = -2 + 3 = 1$.

(e) Find all vertical asymptotes of the graph $y = f(x)$.

6. Let <math>f(x) = 2x^{3/5} + 3x^{-2/5}</math>. Note that the domain of &fnof; is the set of all nonzero real numbers; for example, <math>f(-1) = -2 + 3 = 1</math>.

(e) Find all vertical asymptotes of the graph <math>y = f(x)</math>.
